title: ‘Professional project teams working together happily like a well oiled machine’
pros: Great culture, interesting work skilled staff. Nab are always rewarding staff when goals are achieved. Nab are conscious of creating team moral and excel at bringing teams together.
cons: During major projects NAB should employ the dedicated resource model and insist the resources are located with the project team. In addition moving to a overseas support model will result in slow turn around and miss communications. Keep the resources in Aust NAB.

title: ‘Fantastic environment to work with great people!!’
pros: I really loved working at the bank!! It was something I enjoyed so much, interacting with various types of people and helping them with their needs. I actually really miss my job and would go back in a heart beat if I could get a job at my local branch that didn't require travel each day! (The 1.5 hour commute each way 5 days a week is why I stopped)
cons: The commute! But that was completely circumstantial to me personally.

title: ‘Unless you're comfortable working in a slow but pressurised environment, I do not recommend working at NAB.’
pros: They are accommodating to flexible working, which is a big benefit if you need to pick kids up, or need to work from home.
cons: As with any large and old organisation, there are a lot of system limitations and also a very low risk appetite, making it difficult to create anything new or meaningful.

title: ‘Large and stable but with hints of change a foot.’
pros: Despite the large organization there are many opportunities for growth and development, it's namely up to the individual to seize the initiative. For those who prefer structure and rigor over innovation, the bank largely caters to a more methodical approach however there is growing dissent and investment in disruption. Direct management is very good for coaching and mentoring but the layers above and beyond tend to muddy direct communications and slow decision making. Within the digital space there is strong movement to a more iterative and customer focused value - change is a foot and will require some time to effect impacts but there is an appetite to move the bank forward dynamically over the future; very exciting.
cons: Challenges include the somewhat bloated nature, email and the management of said communication has creates numerous roles due to huge inefficiencies. Senior management is unapproachable and permanently locked in meetings which should be delegated meaning engagement and feedback are often lost. A lot of interaction are driven by rank, as expected in a very hierarchical organization, but this means a lot of time and energy is wasted showing face. Performance and review cycles are annual and leave little room for market growth nor negotiations: you are better off leaving and returning for a higher rate than attempting to negotiate. Finally, there is a trend to hiring temporary worker's over permanent, often choosing permanent staff to take on knowledge hoarding traits to ensure job retention over facilitating a collaborative workplace.

title: ‘Worked at Nab for over 4 years and still counting’
pros: Great work culture with work life balance. The staff at Nab are an awesome bunch and it’s like working with a family where everyone is happy to assist.
cons: Changes in the banking industry has been making it hard to adapt to the changes. With policies and procedures changing, it makes it near impossible to keep up with.

title: ‘I've been here ten years so they must be doing something right!’
pros: With a big company comes a lot of 'big business' perks. Plenty of employee benefits and offers. Salary is quite good and there is a decent feeling that the company would take care of you if you were sick, financially vulnerable or otherwise struggling.
cons: As with all companies there can be a bit of disconnect between the decision makers and the people who are actually effected by the choices and systems that are implemented for them. Sometimes the company can be a little quick to jump the gun with new ideas and procedures.

title: ‘Solid Invaluable lending experience at NAB’
pros: Encouraged to develop your career and opportunities for promotion. Reward and recognition at work. Flexibility with leave at work eg career break, special leave, carer's leave etc
cons: Manage and balance high volumes of quality and accreditation if brokers during peak periods of the year.

title: ‘If your into selling, perfect job’
pros: Staff and customers were the good thing about the job, I worked for them quite a long time, but there main focus now is on sales, loosing all the personal touch, very sad.  Targets were very high, you achieved them but they just wanted more, do they increased your target.  They have lost all it of good faithful staff but your just a number.  The staff work very well as a team but management just want more.....very sad
cons: To achieve targets that are required

title: ‘Best Career opportunities and best place to work at.’
pros: Supportive Staff, Friendly atmosphere, opportunities to advance into other roles, continuous free training while on the job being paid, helpful and understanding staff and managers.
cons: Exceeding the kpi's, dealing with difficult customers.

title: ‘Very welcoming from day they are very supportive the management is all about career progression and making sure you are learning and they do really care about your well being especially in the call centers .... people underestimate but it was actually the’
pros:
Career development 
Equality diversity 
Respect 
Culture & team effort
Many man resources and ease of communication to stakeholders within nab

Career path might be a little difficult even though you work for nab there are still boundaries like competitive colleague or people in nab or external to compete for the one role you really wanted. 
Work like balance is great but like all jobs there is some emphasis on over time in order to succeed

title: ‘My experience working at the nab bank was a good and enthusiastic way of working on my social skills as we'll as my communication skills best place to work always good company and goods colleagues to work with.’
pros: Develop new skills in a different path and achieve a new skill as you go working here is a good place and the best environment I encourage younger and elderly to work here.
cons: You get some challenges as you go but it's normal to do so there re sometime a little things you can and can't understand but I highly recommend this job.

title: ‘Enjoyed the team atmosphere’
pros: Good working environment, great people, sufficient training, RDOs, reasonable holiday allowances to cover staffing (school holidays, Christmas etc)
cons: In 2013 - Time efficiency, there was plenty of training but don't think it was for me. Found it hard to review files and knowing exactly what to look for and what to dismiss. Worked longer hours than paid due to trying to do everything right the first time.

title: ‘Great work environment, with flexible work/life options and good bonuses and rewards program.’
pros: Great bonuses, Fantastic work colleagues, good opportunities to further training and career if so inclined, good work/life balance, ability to take career breaks. From speaking with staff from other banks, NAB appears to be the more ethical and staff friendly of the big 4.
cons: A great deal of emphasis is put on sales results, which can be unreasonable at times, particularly in rural branches. demographics don't appear to be taken into account with sales expectations for particular products, either.

title: ‘Working for the nab had been a great experience for me, where I met great people of differing backgrounds. It has financially provided for me and gave me numerous opportunities for advancement. ’
pros: Great people to work with
cons: The company provided training and support so whatever challenges came my way, I was able to face them and finish the job.

title: ‘Rewarding employer if you manage to perform,can handle constantly changing targets and enjoy a challenge otherwise steer clear.’
pros: Excellent salary and management supportive of work/life balance, provided you perform.
cons: With competitive salary comes expectations of performance which is to be expected. However managements idea of performance often not achievable in a highly competitive market. The bank also appears to have lost its way rewarding long serving staff and acknowledging loyalty and experience. For example, my 20 year anniversary with nab came and went. Later received a cheap signed certificate three months after the fact.
location: Port Macquarie, New South Wales, Australia

title: ‘Incompetent team leader. Most of the staff and upper-management were good but.’
pros: As background, it was a contact centre environment - outbound calls mainly. It was good to have a casual wear day every Friday, and also on pay-day on Wednesday, which was fortnightly. The idea of coaching also was valuable. And most of your co-workers will tend to be friendly, understanding, even helpful.
cons: The initial training for the call centre workers should involve both more product knowledge training, and more hands-on work with the actual future managers. Neglecting these can lead to surprises, and frustration down the track: For example, customers wanting more product information, and  neither you nor the manager having much of a clue as to how to help the customer properly achieve their real goals. And some call centre managers are simply incompetent.

title: ‘I would not work for NAB again. It has a long way to go towards rebuilding its reputation.’
pros: It is difficult to think of anything about working at NAB. The staff were nice but always stressed and did not have time to coach or lead new staff.
cons:
After the banking inquiry working at NAB is not a good place to work. There is clearly a lean now towards only young staff 18-30 as the NAB thinks they will better at ransitioning customers to cheaper channels to provide (ATM, Internet).  
In the business and agri areas staff were constantly stressed and unable to get back to customers in a timely manner.

title: ‘Fantastic culture and encourage staff to achieve their goals and dreams.’
pros: Really good culture! Feel like a family and the management treat everyone fair and equally . There is a huge focus on building strong customer relationships and creating an awesome experience for the customer. Work life balance is pretty good and allways Stevie for people to hit their career goals and progression into new and challenging roles.
cons: Rotating shifts are a challenge not having the stable shifts. The pay is a little lower than other banks but it's cancels it out with the nab culture being more relaxed.

title: ‘NAB has opened up so many doors for me career wise and I could not be prouder to be a part of their amazing team’
pros: NAB truly believes strongly in ensuring everyone works to their best ability and guides them towards their ultimate career goals. The cultural diversity within the company is amazing and ensures a great work/life balance for its employees.
cons: I don't feel like there are any challanges working with NAB

title: ‘Good company, good culture, good people. Just takes forever to get stuff done.’
pros: Great opportunity to develop careers and expand experiences crossing a number of different Financial Services areas. Good culture, good people on the whole
cons: Really slow to get things done. Sometimes you feel like you are battling the world.

title: ‘It seemed like a good idea when offered the role, the experience was bad enough to drive me to resign from the Bank and take a completely different career path for 5 years’
pros: The support for staff was good, the systems were quite good, processes were better than average, portfolio size was good, credit managers were helpful and willing to offer advice.
cons: Training was relatively poor, overall support for new staff was only adequate, sales culture was very intense, management was very sales focused at the expense of many other things

title: ‘Great people, great atmosphere but management culture needs to change.’
pros: Great people, great team dynamic and an increasing focus on flexible work make it a really nice place to work. Middle level managers are typically supportive and understanding. Generally your colleagues are collaborative and genuinely want to drive the company forward.
cons: Many divisional heads and upper level managers have been in the same role for too long and are typically unwilling to change and don't encourage new ideas. Many managers are adamant to pour their resources into dud projects if it was their idea, long after it has lost relevance or feasibility.

title: ‘Great colleague, but poor leadership.’
pros: The people you work with. The feeling of accomplishment when you get to help your customers succeed.
cons: Poor management, with a culture that targets and ambushes staff. Massive hypocrisy between what management say and what management do.

title: ‘The good, bad and ugly’
pros:
The role always keeps me on my toes, policy changes and process changes make sure that I am consistently learning. Nab engage staff and create competitions between branches to keep staff engaged.
There is always opportunity for advancement.
cons:
Targets are a big thing at the NAB, if you work in a major city or a rural area they are the same.
Support from management is lacking as they are currently demoting people and reducing hours as branches don't have the foot traffic as they used to.

title: ‘The talk is talked but the walk isn't always walked in the right direction’
pros: Embracing innovation, looking to the future, diversity pretty well covers all groups of society enterprise wide and is embraced and encouraged. Pockets of great people driving change in challenging environments.
cons: Leaders (middle) not always leading from the front with enthusiasm and a clear path to engage the team to follow. Sometimes seems that messages up the line don't make it through a wall of misinformation and lack of proper accountability for poor leadership behaviour and decision making (or lack of decision making).

title: ‘My experience with NAB is it seeks to foster a positive working environment for its employees’
pros:
Career development once you have your foot in the door is available.
NAB supports the community and encourages staff 2 days per year (paid leave) to volunteer in the community.
cons: Challenges involve staff shortages as well as at times insufficient training of staff prior to commencing work. Staff an feel \"thrown in the deep end\"

title: ‘National Australia the place I would like to goback to.’

I was respected by my colleagues and my managers trusted me .
the perks were good . the morale of the group good and the support form management good

title: ‘The first day I started work at NAB, I knew I'd made a great decision.’

title: ‘Great career advancement opportunities for those that work hard and want to climb.’

Career advancement opportunities... and variety of roles/areas to work in.
Focus on improving \"family friendly\" workplace.

title: ‘A great organisation to work for and I have nothing by good things to say about them.’

title: ‘I have enjoyed working at NAB for over 3 years and I intend on continuing my career in my current branch if I get the opportunity once my contract ends.’

cons: Sales Expectations. Annual Leave must be all used and booked in up to 12 months in advance. Transferring from one branch to another is not an easy process and you are subjected to the same recruitment process whether internal or not.

title: ‘It has been great working experience with valuable lessons.’
pros: NAB providers great support for work life balance and work flexibility that makes it easier for employees to lead our life. Also we are given great support and guidance for self development and career orientation.

title: ‘I was grateful the nab wanted me 15 years ago and now the nab is grateful for my knowledge, gravitas and service’

cons: You don't get a contract with the company straight away, there is a wait time.

title: ‘A charictor building and rewarding experience’

cons: Large stock market is a heavily regulated industry that requires continuous learning
location: North Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

title: ‘I had 35 wonderful years working across the globe for the NAB group, made numerous friends and don't for one minute regret the experience.’

cons: At times, too much emphasis placed on bottom line results with little thought given to the impact such has on individuals (eg forced redundancies and lack of trained staff). As with the broader banking industry, needs to continue work in building trust in the general community.

title: ‘Absolutely love working for NAB!’

As a woman over 40 who was happy to specialise and intentionally not manage a team (introvert with strong, valuable specialist skills), there was a strong drive to take on management roles...part of addressing gender equality. Some people can truly add significant business balue without managing people.

title: ‘With political care and much patience, I enjoyed working with and learning from lots of great people, and being able to make a modest difference.’
pros: Fantastic employment conditions - work flexibility, pay, accommodating family obligations, mat leave, etc.  Also has many really good, very professional people, partic at 'Head of' and GM level.

Huge waste caused by a highly political and self-serving leadership environment, constant re-structuring and retrenching, and then subsequently rehiring the same capabilities.  No recognition of the value of refining and developing what is there, just constantly looking outside for the elusive magic solution.

title: ‘One of the best jobs in a long career of ups and downs.’

cons: Please note that the categories I rated low are because I contract and am therefore excluded from these areas. As I understand they aren't bad for actual employees.

title: ‘Survival of the fittest ’

cons: Office politics, career advancement mostly due to who you know, rather than experience. So many layers in management structure, roles created out of thin air by some managers left those with genuine drive and experience, losing out to external hires.

title: ‘Loved working for the company, I worked with a great team and it never felt like work really.’
pros: Great work life balance, most days your finished by 4:30! Very retail based and great incentives and team activities.
cons: The sales leads are a little tricky at times.

title: ‘Hard work but a career worth pursuing’
pros: Hi staff engagement, hi staff enablement. Room to develop your skill set and  be promoted through the ranks . Availability to work in Business , Retail , Corporate etc so lots of career diversity available

title: ‘Terrible organisation to work for. Run by stealth and people only worried about their own bonuses as opposed to the customers. Be out as soon as I find something else. ’

cons: Ambitious colleagues undermine and take credit for your ideas and work. The culture is highly competitive and while teamwork is the mantra very few within the organisation practise this.

title: ‘NAB today is far different from I first started working for them 23 years ago.’
pros: Good training & educational courses provided

title: ‘Very positive and the only reason I left was because my role was specifically focused on General Insurance and there wasn't a lot of career development opportunities unless you had a banking background’
pros: Cohesive culture. Everyone was clear about what our objectives were, and strategies to implement to get there. Management put a lot of effort and went to great expense to ensure staff had the opportunity to bond, and work together as a team.
cons: The targets in place were a stretch and almost out of reach in many cases, due to circumstances beyond the control of staff

title: ‘A year or so out of my life!’
pros: The redundancy package after the 3rd restructure of my 15 month employment
cons: Restructure after restructure, poor senior leadership, lack of direction, low morale, ancient systems, poor processes, enterprise behaviours policy used as a tool to oppress rather than a standard to attain
location: St Leonards, New South Wales, Australia

title: ‘I had a great experience developing relationships with customers and work colleagues and building experience in banking’
pros: Supportive and happy working environment. Meeting new customers from all walks of life and building bonds with regulars. Feeling satisfied when meeting the customers needs etc
cons: Having to meet monthly targets but with practice and experience becomes easy.. having to satisfy the needs of every customer can often be a challenge but you get there in the end.

title: ‘No regrets about working at NAB but wouldn't choose to work there again’
pros:
Flexibility (provided targets are hit)
Remuneration (once targets are hit)
CSO & paraplanning support
Working with & training branch staff
cons:
Lack of training on job specific tasks & systems
Big focus on 'managers targets' so they validate
Big difference between bankers & commercial planners to retail planners
Constant change of management
Constant change of targets & roles
Confusing scorecard & questionable targets
'Background' & 'shadow' targets

title: ‘Fake it till you make it!’
pros: Excellent team culture, fantastic energy, and plenty of opportunities to progress.  Excellent staff in general.
cons: Inconsistency in procedures, lack of general knowledge due to under-developed training processes, and an unfortunate sink-or-swim attitude which impacts on work/life balance.

title: ‘My Training at NAB went a long way.’
pros: So much room to move career wise. Nab invest a lot in putting employees through training & great workshop sessions to continuously keep them up skilled.
cons: Strict policies, and a lot of policies to remember. Always busy & can be stressful. Working well under constant pressure is a MUST.

title: ‘Only work here if you want to look good to future employers’
pros: I worked in the customer service centre. Training was great, and colleagues were all fantastic. The best thing though, was probably that working at NAB made me more appealing to other employers.
cons:
- Didn't actually know what the job was until my first day
- Constantly changing shifts. You're meant to know your shift a month ahead, but shifts have been known to change within 48 hours notice 
- Miscommunication about shifts in application and interview stage 
- Opportunities to move up in the ranks only available if you want to become a team leader 
- Micromanagement of breaks
- The need to get to work and set up the computer 15 - 30 minutes before start time to avoid being \"late\" (with no overtime pay)

title: ‘It was a great job and challenging too but felt undervalued as a casual.’
pros: Provided training locally and I was paid for the training time, uniform provided. Co-workers very helpful and supportive in my training process. Enjoyed working in the position and customer service. Was grateful they employed me as a mature aged person.
cons: In the beginning of my employment I was told I may have the opportunity to gain permanent part-time work 3 days a week. They changed their mind and I was very disappointed. Also my hours were reduced in relieving and after not working for 3 weeks I was expected to drive to Orbost for 1 day's relief, being a round trip of 122 kms using my car and paying for petrol. They didn't reimburse travelling expenses because I was casual. I made 6 trips to Orbost over the 2 months I worked for them. I explained to the the Store Manager it was not viable for me to travel 122 km for 1 day, especially being unemployed. I have not been asked to work since then.

title: ‘Good company to work for but difficult to navigate’
pros: Flexibility, budget to do things, supportive policies
cons: Very large company sometimes feel like a number, hard to get things done with so many stakeholders, need to be able to find your way independently

title: ‘Would definitely recommend for anyone to work here. ’
pros: Work/life balance was the best thing for me in NAB.
cons: Hot desk was a challenge for me every day sitting in different places in 700 Bourke in NAB

title: ‘Shocking; i have have 2 roles within nab in the past 4 years, retail banking good luck trying to move up the chain without connection. business banking, be prepared to work for peanuts and pump out work way above your pay grade.’
pros: The good thing is the team environment, they are structured to work like a family tree.
cons: Actually having the organisation coincide with your personal life

title: ‘Working at NAB was positive and rewarding, with a great focus on development and a sustainable future’

title: ‘It's work and it pays the bills, but if you want to work in a team full of people who are passionate about what they do, this may not be the place for you.’
pros: They paid me......and that's about where the positives end.
cons: Really stifling culture

title: ‘Never a dull moment when you're on a project’
pros: NAB offers an inclusive environment that appreciates the skills that people bring to the table. It encourages diversity and is one of the more community minded large organsiations in Australia.
cons: Performance management leaves a lot to be desired.

title: ‘Overall a great place to work just be prepared to put up with some clunky systems which will cause frustration’
pros: The working environment, the people, the location, the opportunities
cons: Extremely process driven with old slow systems, constant restructuring, constant change in management could all get a bit exhausting

title: ‘Learning, laugh, memories’
pros: Career progression: your out out is above and reaching your goals with your people leaders then new doors will be open when asked or given.
cons: Competing with the other major banks to make revenue for the business.
location: Inner west Sydney Rhodes to Balmain

title: ‘Poor onboarding to set you up for failure, wouldnt recommend to my enemy.’
pros: Loyal Customers. Diversity and equal opportunity.
cons: I joined NAB after having served another big four bank for 14 years due to the close proximity of the NAB business centre I would be based out of, turned out to be the worst career move. Poor on boarding and the management had no clue on how to on board new to bank staff. My first formal training was booked in close to 3 months after I had taken up the role. Without any formal training I was asked to deal with a portfolio of clients within two weeks into my role, setting me up for failure. The portfolio was also vacant for 8 months before I was appointed so customers weren't happy and my work phone wouldn't stop ringing including weekends. Overall poor experience, wouldn't recommend NAB to my enemy. Also if you have an appetite for commercial lending don't get misled by NAB small business, their bankers courtesy handful of introducers just do home lending to business customers and achieve revenue targets. I saw no future at NAB and resigned in 4 months. The management showed a lot of desperation in me taking over a portfolio of disgruntled customers and sorting their issues which wasn't taken care of in the last 8 months.
